description: Standpipe and hose system installation requirements

questions.question: What is a Class I standpipe system?
options: System with 1-1/2 inch hose connections for trained personnel
System with 2-1/2 inch hose connections for fire department use
Combined system with both hose sizes
questions.explanation: Class I standpipe systems provide 2-1/2 inch hose connections for fire department use. They are designed for full-scale firefighting operations.

questions.question: What is a Class II standpipe system?
options: System with 1-1/2 inch hose connections for building occupants
questions.explanation: Class II standpipe systems provide 1-1/2 inch hose connections intended for use by trained building occupants or fire brigade members until the fire department arrives.

questions.question: What is a Class III standpipe system?
options: A combined system with both 2-1/2 inch and 1-1/2 inch connections
A system for high-rise buildings only
questions.explanation: Class III standpipe systems provide both 2-1/2 inch connections for fire department use and 1-1/2 inch connections for building occupant use.

questions.question: At what building height are standpipes typically required?
questions.explanation: Standpipes are generally required in buildings exceeding 50 feet in height or more than 4 stories, though requirements vary by building code.

questions.question: What is the minimum flow rate for a Class I standpipe system?
questions.explanation: Class I and III systems require a minimum of 500 gpm for the first standpipe, with 250 gpm for each additional standpipe up to a maximum of 1000-1250 gpm.

questions.question: What is the minimum pressure required at the topmost outlet of a Class I standpipe?
questions.explanation: Class I standpipes require a minimum of 100 psi residual pressure at the topmost outlet when flowing 500 gpm from the most remote standpipe.

questions.question: What is the maximum pressure allowed at a standpipe hose connection?
questions.explanation: Maximum pressure at hose connections shall not exceed 175 psi. Pressure-reducing devices may be required at lower levels in tall buildings.

questions.question: What is an automatic standpipe system?
options: A system that opens valves automatically
A system connected to a water supply capable of supplying demand automatically
A system with electric pumps only
questions.explanation: An automatic standpipe is connected to a water supply capable of supplying the system demand automatically. It may be wet or dry but has permanent water supply.

questions.question: What is a manual standpipe system?
options: A system without permanent water supply, relying on FDC
A system with manual fire pumps
questions.explanation: A manual standpipe has no permanent water supply. It relies entirely on the fire department connection (FDC) to supply water during operations.

questions.question: What thread type is standard for 2-1/2 inch fire hose connections?
questions.explanation: 2-1/2 inch hose connections use NH (National Hose) thread, also called NST (National Standard Thread), unless local requirements specify different threads.

questions.question: How high above the floor should standpipe hose connections be mounted?
questions.explanation: Hose connections shall be located so the center is between 3 and 5 feet above the floor for accessibility.

questions.question: What is the maximum horizontal distance from any point in a building to a Class I or III standpipe?
questions.explanation: Standpipes must be located so all portions of the building are within 200 feet of a hose connection, considering 100 feet of hose length plus 100 feet of water stream.

questions.question: What is the minimum pipe size for a Class I standpipe riser?
questions.explanation: Class I and Class III standpipe risers must be at least 4 inches in diameter. Class II risers may be smaller based on hydraulic calculations.

questions.question: How many fire department connections (FDCs) are required for a standpipe system?
questions.explanation: FDCs are sized for total system demand. Multiple FDCs may be required based on flow requirements and fire department access.

questions.question: What flow rate is required for Class II standpipe systems?
questions.explanation: Class II standpipes require a minimum of 100 gpm at 65 psi from the most hydraulically remote hose connection.

questions.question: When are pressure-reducing valves required on standpipe hose connections?
questions.explanation: Pressure-reducing devices are required when the pressure at hose connections exceeds 175 psi to protect firefighters and equipment.

questions.question: What is required when a standpipe system is combined with a sprinkler system?
options: Combined system meets requirements of both NFPA 13 and NFPA 14
questions.explanation: Combined systems must meet the requirements of both NFPA 13 for sprinklers and NFPA 14 for standpipes, including water supply calculations.

questions.question: What is a semi-automatic dry standpipe?
options: A system that is partially filled with water
A dry system with automatic water supply upon activation of remote device
A system with half manual operation
questions.explanation: Semi-automatic dry standpipes are normally dry but have a deluge valve that opens automatically when a remote activation device is operated, admitting water.

questions.question: Where are horizontal standpipe runs permitted?
options: In buildings of unlimited area per floor
As needed to reach remote areas within coverage distance
questions.explanation: Horizontal runs may extend from risers to provide hose connections within the required coverage distance. They must be hydraulically calculated.

questions.question: What valve type is required at standpipe hose connections?
questions.explanation: Hose valves (hose connection valves) must be listed and are typically angle or straight pattern valves designed for fire hose service.

questions.question: What is the water supply duration requirement for standpipe systems?
questions.explanation: Standpipe water supplies must provide the required flow for a minimum of 30 minutes. Some jurisdictions require longer durations.

questions.question: What test is required for standpipe systems after installation?
options: Hydrostatic test at 200 psi or 50 psi above working pressure
questions.explanation: Standpipe systems require a hydrostatic test at 200 psi for 2 hours, or 50 psi above the maximum system pressure, whichever is greater.

questions.question: Where must standpipe hose connections be located in stairways?
options: At an intermediate floor level landing or main floor level
At the bottom of each flight
questions.explanation: Hose connections in stairways must be at the main floor level landing or the intermediate landing between floor levels, accessible without entering the floor.

questions.question: What is required when standpipes serve multiple zones in high-rise buildings?
options: Separate risers or zone control valves with pressure regulation
questions.explanation: Tall buildings may require pressure zones to maintain pressure limits at hose connections. Each zone may have separate risers or pressure-regulating devices.

questions.question: What marking is required on pressure-reducing hose valves?
options: Factory set pressure and flow characteristics
questions.explanation: Pressure-reducing hose valves must be marked with their factory-set pressure and flow characteristics for identification during use and maintenance.

questions.question: For a building with 3 standpipes, what is the total flow requirement?
questions.explanation: First standpipe = 500 gpm, second = 250 gpm, third = 250 gpm. Total = 1000 gpm. Maximum requirement is typically 1000-1250 gpm regardless of additional standpipes.

questions.question: What is the hydraulic calculation requirement for express standpipe risers?
options: Must account for friction loss in entire riser height
questions.explanation: Express risers (risers passing through floors without connections) must account for full friction loss while providing required pressure at the first connection.

questions.question: When calculating combined sprinkler/standpipe demand, how is the demand determined?
options: Use larger of the two demands
Sprinkler demand plus standpipe at reduced rate
Use standpipe demand plus sprinkler design area demand simultaneously
questions.explanation: Combined systems calculate the greater of: standpipe demand alone, or sprinkler demand plus the standpipe demand calculated per NFPA 14.

questions.question: What is the K-factor requirement for 2-1/2 inch hose valves in hydraulic calculations?
options: Use outlet coefficient based on valve type
questions.explanation: Hydraulic calculations must use the appropriate outlet coefficient (K-factor) based on the hose valve type. This varies by manufacturer and valve design.

questions.question: What pressure-regulating device setting is required for hose connections?
options: Field adjustable to deliver 100 psi residual at rated flow
questions.explanation: Pressure-regulating devices must be field-adjustable to deliver the required residual pressure (100 psi for Class I/III) at the rated flow.

questions.question: For roof manifold standpipe systems, what is required?
options: Two or more risers connected at the roof with hose connections
questions.explanation: Roof manifolds connect multiple risers at the roof level, providing redundancy and flexibility for firefighting operations. They require careful hydraulic design.

questions.question: What is the inspection frequency for standpipe hose connections per NFPA 25?
questions.explanation: Standpipe hose connections must be inspected annually. This includes checking caps, gaskets, valve operation, and signage.

questions.question: What flow test is required for automatic standpipes per NFPA 25?
options: Annual flow test at most remote connection
questions.explanation: Automatic standpipes require a flow test every 5 years at the system demand to verify pressure and flow meet design requirements.

questions.question: What is required for horizontal exits in standpipe coverage?
options: No coverage required at horizontal exits
Hose connections on both sides of the horizontal exit
questions.explanation: Buildings with horizontal exits require standpipe coverage such that hose connections are available on both sides of the horizontal exit barrier.

questions.question: When retrofitting an existing building with standpipes, what pressure is acceptable?
options: 65 psi minimum for existing Class I systems
questions.explanation: Existing systems may be permitted to operate at 65 psi rather than 100 psi in some circumstances, subject to AHJ approval and NFPA 14 provisions.

questions.question: What is the FDC inlet size requirement for standpipe systems?
options: Sized for system demand, minimum two 2-1/2 inch inlets
questions.explanation: FDC must be sized for system demand. For systems requiring 500+ gpm, minimum two 2-1/2 inch inlets (or equivalent) are required.

questions.question: In seismic areas, what additional requirements apply to standpipe systems?
options: Flexible connections and seismic bracing per NFPA 13
questions.explanation: Standpipe systems in seismic areas must include flexible couplings at building movement joints and seismic bracing per NFPA 13 requirements.

questions.question: What is required for standpipe systems during construction?
options: No standpipe until building is complete
Temporary standpipe as building rises above specified height
questions.explanation: Standpipes must be installed as construction progresses and be operational when the building reaches heights requiring standpipe protection.

questions.question: What identification is required at standpipe system control valves?
options: Sign indicating area served and open position
questions.explanation: Control valves must be identified with signs indicating the portion of the system served and must indicate whether the valve is open or closed.

questions.question: Where are cabinet-type hose stations permitted?
options: Class II systems with 1-1/2 inch connections
questions.explanation: Hose cabinets with pre-connected hose are typical for Class II systems. They provide 1-1/2 inch hose for occupant use.
